quizzes.title: History Quiz: Movie and Portrayal
quizzes.description: Test your history knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering History, leader, drama. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: Judy Dench won an Academy Award for her portrayal of Queen Elizabeth I in the movie Shakespeare in Love. What other queen did she play in the movie Mrs. Brown?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Queen Victoria

questions.question: What historical figure was played by Brian Keith in the movie The Wind and the Lion, which was loosely based on the Perdicaris incident of 1904?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Theodore Roosevelt

questions.question: What actress won an Academy Award for her portrayal of British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher in the movie The Iron Lady?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Meryl Streep

questions.question: This country, famous for its fjords, has an extensive coastline, facing the North Atlantic Ocean and the Barents Sea.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Norway

questions.question: What European politician and former Prime Minister co-wrote the anthem of a famous football club?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Silvio Berlusconi

questions.question: The movie A Man for All Seasons portrays Sir Thomas More, the 16th-century Lord Chancellor of England, who refused to take an Oath of Supremacy declaring the monarch the Supreme Head of the Church of England. Who was the monarch?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: King Henry VIII

questions.question: Which king was portrayed by Colin Firth in the Oscar-winning movie The Kings Speech?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: George VI

questions.question: What two colors, when mixed together, make the color purple?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Red and Blue

questions.question: Which of these actors has portrayed and Irish revolutionary leader, a German industrialist who employed over 1000 Jews in his factories, and a Scottish hero?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Liam Neeson

questions.question: What actress won an Academy Award for her portrayal of Elizabeth I, the Virgin Queen in the 1998 biographical film Elizabeth?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Cate Blanchett

questions.question: What English actress has played tragic historical characters such as Isadora Duncan, Anne Boleyn and Mary, Queen of Scots?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Vanessa Redgrave

questions.question: What WWII operation is NOT correctly matched with its code name?

options.text: Barbarossa - German offensive against the USSR
Overlord - the operation that launched the invasion of German-occupied western Europe
Juno - German naval operation to disturb allied supplies to Norway

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Arcadia - Allied offensive in Italy

questions.question: Which of the following actors has NOT played King Arthur?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Corin Redgrave

questions.question: In the historical drama Braveheart, Mel Gibson portrays 13th-century Scottish warrior William Wallace who led the Scots in the First War of Scottish Independence against this English king.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Edward I

questions.question: Sachertorte, a specific type of chocolate cake, was invented by chance in this European city.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Vienna

quizzes.title: Geography Quiz: Presidents and Independence
quizzes.description: Test your geography knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Geography, invention, theodore. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: The Phillips screwdriver was first used by the multinational electronics manufacturer Philips Electronics.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: False

questions.question: How were presidents Frankin Roosevelt and Theodore Roosevelt related?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: they were fifth cousins

questions.question: The word serif in the context of typefaces refers to what?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: a small projecting feature

questions.question: The classic commercial for what product used the line There is a man in the bathtub!
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Mr. Bubble

questions.question: Angola won its independence in 1975, from what country?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Portugal

questions.question: Where were the 1936 Summer Olympics held?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Berlin

questions.question: No Oscars were awarded during the years of World War II, because the gold for the statuettes was too expensive to acquire.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: False

questions.question: Were was it raining for singer Buddy Holly?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: In his heart

questions.question: In 1970, the hit Snowbird launched whose successful career?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Anne Murray

questions.question: Where was the idea of making purchases on a credit card first described?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: novel

questions.question: What color is powdered caffeine?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: white

questions.question: What term means the possible transformation of harsh environments into ones suited for living?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: terraforming

questions.question: What Italian dish consists of salami, anchovies, artichokes, olives, and other appetizers?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: antipasto

questions.question: The drug Minoxidil was created to treat what?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: loss of hair

questions.question: What important invention did American Jonas Salk make in 1954?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: polio vaccine

quizzes.title: History Quiz: World War and Us
quizzes.description: Test your history knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering History, world, telegram. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: What was the only part of the US military establishment that was reasonably prepared for war at the beginning of US participation in World War One?

options.text: the US government in Washington DC

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The US Navy

questions.question: Which of the following were factors that caused the US to enter World War One on the side of the Allies (Britain, France, Russia and other smaller nations)?

options.text: Britain and France were democracies, while German and Austrian governments were much less democratic.
US cultural ties with Britain and France
German sinking of US merchant ships by German submarines

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: All of these

questions.question: What do directors Tony Scott and Sir Ridley Scott have in common?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: They are brothers.

questions.question: Most Americans were angry when they heard about the Zimmerman Telegram.  What did the German foreign minister promised Mexico in this telegram?

options.text: a large reward in gold which would be part of the indemnity the Allies would pay after the German victory (which of course did not occur) if Mexico declared war on the US
the latest submarine technology in return for German Submarine bases in Mexico
territory in the southwest United States which had once been Mexican territory if Mexico would form an alliance with Germany against the US

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: territory in the southwest United States which had once been Mexican territory if Mexico would form an alliance with Germany against the US

questions.question: World War one broke out in 1914 but the US did not enter the war as a belligerent until what year?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 1917

questions.question: In World War One US Army Sergeant Alvin York is best remembered as which of the following?

options.text: A battlefield hero and Medal of Honor recipient
A traitor who gave military information to the Germans
The first American killed in France
An army pilot who was the first to become an ace by shooting down five enemy planes

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: A battlefield hero and Medal of Honor recipient

questions.question: What is significant about the history of the Republic of Armenia?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: first Christian state

questions.question: US forces played a major part in stopping the final great German offensive of World War One partly by stopping the German advance at this location.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Chateau-Thierry

questions.question: What future US President fought as an artillery captain in World War One?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Harry Truman

questions.question: When US troops reached Europe to join the fighting in World War One, they had to learn quickly how to fight this type of warfare.

options.text: air warfare which completely dominated the battlefield as well as the air.
mobile warfare using cavalry and fast moving foot soldiers

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: nearly static trench warfare

questions.question: This horror film, which focuses on a love triangle, marked Tony Scotts directorial debut.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Hunger

questions.question: A revolution in one of the main powers eventually forced that nation to drop out of World War One. Fortunately for the Allies the entry of the US largely made up for the loss of this nation. What was the nation?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Russia

questions.question: The US President said that the purpose of the US fighting in World War One was which of the following?

options.text: to gain colonies for the United States
to make the world safe for democracy
to show that the US was a powerful nation

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: to make the world safe for democracy

questions.question: Who was President of the United States during World War One?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Woodrow Wilson

questions.question: Who was the military commander of US Army forces in Europe in World War One?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: John Pershing

quizzes.title: Entertainment Quiz: Tony Scott and Movie
quizzes.description: Test your entertainment knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Entertainment, peach, death. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: What 1998 conspiracy thriller directed by Tony Scott was the highest grossing movie of the 1990s?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Enemy of the State

questions.question: When this historical figure married the Duke of Orléans (Henry II of France) in 1533, she brought with her to France some Italian chefs who had recipes for flavoured ices or sorbets.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Catherine de Medici

questions.question: Gelato, which is made with milk, cream, sugar, fresh fruit and nut purees, originated in this country.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Italy

questions.question: Which of the following Tony Scott movies does NOT star Denzel Washington?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Spy Game

questions.question: Two days prior to his death, Tony Scott was with this actor exploring locations for a sequel to Top Gun.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Tom Cruise

questions.question: What famous explorer is credited with bringing to Italy the technique of making ice cream?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Marco Polo

questions.question: Which of the following frozen desserts does NOT contain dairy ingredients?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: sorbet

questions.question: Who stars as a private eye and former Secret Service agent in Tony Scotts action movie The Last Boy Scout?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Bruce Willis

questions.question: It is generally accepted that the name of the ice cream dessert sundae originated from which of the following words?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Sunday

questions.question: The Peach Melba was named in honor of Australian soprano Nellie Melba, who in 1892 was performing in Wagners opera Lohengrin at Covent Garden. The French chef at the Savoy Hotel, London created the new dessert, and to display it, he used an ice sculpture of what animal?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: swan

questions.question: What Roman Emperor, who ruled from 54 to 68, ordered ice to be brought from the mountains and combined it with fruit toppings?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Nero

questions.question: What 2010 action thriller, starring Denzel Washington and Chris Pine, was the last movie directed by Tony Scott?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Unstoppable

questions.question: Director Tony Scott stated that while making this movie, he stole from all race movies to date ... then tried to build on them.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Days of Thunder

questions.question: What thriller set in Mexico and directed by Tony Scott, starred Kevin Costner, Madeleine Stowe and Anthony Quinn?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Revenge

questions.question: In 2010, Tony Scott and Ridley Scott produced the feature film adaptation of this action-adventure television series about fictional soldiers of fortune.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The A-Team

quizzes.title: History Quiz: Swimming and Swimmer
quizzes.description: Test your history knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering History, lausanne, hooloovoo. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: How many meters can be swum underwater in swimming races from the start and from each turn?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 15

questions.question: In a relay race, which swimmer is called an anchor?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: the one who swims last

questions.question: Australian Sydney Cavill is credited as the originator of this swimming stroke, which was first swum in competition in 1933 and is the newest of the four major strokes.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: butterfly

questions.question: What French Enlightenment writer, historian and philosopher made the following remark about ice cream: Ice-cream is exquisite. What a pity it isnt illegal.?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Voltaire

questions.question: What painter wrote the following lines to describe to his brother Theo how he composed a sky, The dark blue sky is spotted with clouds of an even darker blue than the fundamental blue of intense cobalt, and others of a lighter blue, like the bluish white of the Milky Way..?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Vincent van Gogh

questions.question: Who is the first swimmer in history to have won eight gold medals in a single Olympics?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Michael Phelps

questions.question: In which of the two swimming strokes can the flip turn be used in competitions?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: free style and backstroke

questions.question: At the age of 14 she became the youngest-ever female Olympic champion in swimming. She is the first female swimmer to have ever won the same swimming event at 3 consecutive Summer Olympics.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Krisztina Egerszegi

questions.question: The mixture of shaved ice and evaporated milk, known as Halo-halo, originated in this country.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Philippines

questions.question: In what sci-fi comedy series is the Hooloovoo described as a superintelligent shade of the color blue that participated in the construction of the starship Heart of Gold?

options.text: The Hitchhikers Guide to the Galaxy

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Hitchhikers Guide to the Galaxy

questions.question: What US First Lady served ice cream at her husbands second Inaugural Ball in 1813?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Dolley Madison

questions.question: During which Olympics were swimming goggles first used?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 1976 Montreal

questions.question: What federation, based in Lausanne, Switzerland, governs competitive swimming?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: FINA

questions.question: In what order are the strokes in Individual Medley swum?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Butterfly, Backstroke, Breaststroke, Freestyle

questions.question: What stroke is almost universally used during a freestyle swimming race?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: front crawl

quizzes.title: Science Quiz: Country and People
quizzes.description: Test your science knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Science, people, masochism. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: What plant was named after a French ambassador who was sent to Portugal to negotiate the marriage of six-year-old Princess Marguerite de Valois?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: the tobacco plant (Nicotiana)

questions.question: What people of Africa are also known as the Blue People due to the indigo colour of their veils?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Tuareg

questions.question: What countrys National Football Team wear blue in honour of the royal House of Savoy which unified the country?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Italy

questions.question: Where is the color blue located on the optical spectrum?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: between violet and green

questions.question: What blue movie is not correctly matched with the starring actors?

options.text: Mickey Blue Eyes - Tom Cruise, Elizabeth Hurley
Blue Thunder - Roy Sheider, Malcolm McDowell
My Blue Heaven - Steve Martin, Joan Cusack
Blue Velvet - Isabella Rossellini, Dennis Hopper

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Mickey Blue Eyes - Tom Cruise, Elizabeth Hurley

questions.question: What technology term comes from the epithet of a king who united the tribes of Denmark into a single kingdom?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Bluetooth

questions.question: What word supposedly originated from the name of a soldier who was ridiculed because of his excessive devotion to Napoleon?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: chauvinism

questions.question: The term masochism is derived from the name of Leopold von Sacher-Masoch, an Austrian writer who penned this novel.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Venus in Furs

questions.question: What clothing item was named after a British Army Major General who commanded the Light Brigade during the Crimean War?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: cardigan

questions.question: What disease is named after the main character of an epic poem by Italian physician and poet Girolamo Fracastoro?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Syphilis

questions.question: Who composed The Blue Danube waltz, which has become a sort of unofficial Austrian national anthem?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Johann Strauss II

questions.question: Which of these popular types of cheese is not blue?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Gouda

questions.question: The word maverick refers to a person who refuses to abide by the dictates of a group and was derived from the name of Samuel Maverick. Who was he?

options.text: a land agent who refused to lower rents
a man who illegally sold whiskey
a rancher who refused to brand his cattle despite the common practice at the time
a man who refused to pay taxes

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: a rancher who refused to brand his cattle despite the common practice at the time

questions.question: What expression was used in the 18th century for women who cared about culture and intellectual life and disregarded fashion?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Bluestocking

questions.question: The term blue blood was originally used to refer to the the pale skin and prominent blue veins of nobles from this country.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Spain
